Package danogl

Class GameObject

java.lang.Object
danogl.GameObject
Direct Known Subclasses:
Camera
public class GameObject
extends java.lang.Object
Represents an object in the game. For example, an object has dimensions, a certain position, it has a velocity, an image that represents it, and it can potentially collide with other GameObjects.
Author:
Dan Nirel

  • Field Details

    • freeCalculationsVector

      protected MutableVector2 freeCalculationsVector
      Use with care. this a general-purpose container vector for calculations where it's undesirable to create a new vector. use only in the main thread.

  • Constructor Details

    • GameObject

      public GameObject​(Vector2 topLeftCorner, Vector2 dimensions, Renderable renderable)
      Construct a new GameObject instance.
      Parameters:
      topLeftCorner - Position of the object, in window coordinates (pixels). Note that (0,0) is the top-left corner of the window.
      dimensions - Width and height in window coordinates.
      renderable - The renderable representing the object. Can be null, in which case the GameObject will not be rendered.

  • Method Details

    • update

      public void update​(float deltaTime)
      Should be called once per frame.
      Parameters:
      deltaTime - The time elapsed, in seconds, since the last frame. Can be used to determine a new position/velocity by multiplying this delta with the velocity/acceleration respectively and adding to the position/velocity: velocity += deltaTime*acceleration pos += deltaTime*velocity

    • render

      public void render​(java.awt.Graphics2D g)
      An overload of render(Graphics2D, Camera) for the default camera.

    • render

      public void render​(java.awt.Graphics2D g, Camera camera)
      Renders the game object if the Renderable is not null. Should be called in the rendering phase (i.e., not within an update). The method is automatically called if the object was added to an active GameObjectCollection.
      Parameters:
      g - The graphics objects passed to GameManager.render.
      camera - The active camera

    • shouldCollideWith

      public boolean shouldCollideWith​(GameObject other)
      Should this object be allowed to collide the the specified other object. If both this object returns true for the other, and the other returns true for this one, the collisions may occur when they overlap, meaning that their respective onCollisionEnter/onCollisionStay/onCollisionExit will be called. Note that this assumes that both objects have been added to the same GameObjectCollection, and that its handleCollisions() method is invoked.
      Parameters:
      other - The other GameObject.
      Returns:
      true if the objects should collide. This does not guarantee a collision would actually collide if they overlap, since the other object has to confirm this one as well.

    • onCollisionEnter

      public void onCollisionEnter​(GameObject other, Collision collision)
      Called on the first frame of a collision.
      Parameters:
      other - The GameObject with which a collision occurred.
      collision - Information regarding this collision. A reasonable elastic behavior can be achieved with: setVelocity(getVelocity().flipped(collision.getNormal()));

    • onCollisionStay

      public void onCollisionStay​(GameObject other, Collision collision)
      Called on every frame of a collision with a given object, including the first.
      Parameters:
      other - The collision partner.
      collision - Information regarding this collision.

    • onCollisionExit

      public void onCollisionExit​(GameObject other)
      Called once, AFTER a collision ended.
      Parameters:
      other - The former collision partner.

    • getCenter

      public Vector2 getCenter()
      Get the center of this GameObject, in window coordinates.

    • setCenter

      public void setCenter​(Vector2 center)
      Set the new center position of the object, in window coordinates.

    • getTopLeftCorner

      public Vector2 getTopLeftCorner()
      Get the top-left corner of this GameObject, in window coordinates.

    • setTopLeftCorner

      public void setTopLeftCorner​(Vector2 topLeftCorner)
      Set the top-left corner of this object. Moves the entire object so that its top-left corner is as specified.

    • getVelocity

      public Vector2 getVelocity()
      Returns the current velocity.

    • setVelocity

      public void setVelocity​(Vector2 velocity)
      Set the object's velocity.

    • getDimensions

      public Vector2 getDimensions()
      Get the object's width and height.

    • setDimensions

      public void setDimensions​(Vector2 dimensions)
      Sets the object's width and height. Its center remains the same, while its corners move.

    • getTag

      public java.lang.String getTag()
      Gets the object's tag. The tag has no inherent meaning on its own and is not used by the GameObject class itself; it can be assigned any meaning by the user of the class, and is simply a convenience placeholder for custom info.

    • setTag

      public void setTag​(java.lang.String tag)
      Sets the object's tag. The tag has no inherent meaning on its own and is not used by the GameObject class itself; it can be assigned any meaning by the user of the class, and is simply a convenience placeholder for custom info.

    • addComponent

      public void addComponent​(Component component)
      Add a component to the GameObject. A component includes a method that should be executed on every update.

    • removeComponent

      public void removeComponent​(Component component)
      remove a component from the GameObject. A component includes a method that should be executed on every update.

    • renderer

      public RendererComponent renderer()
      access to attributes concerning the rendering of the object (the Renderable that represents it, the Renderable's angle etc.)

    • transform

      public Transform transform()
      access to attributes concerning the object's transform (position, dimensions, etc.)

    • getCoordinateSpace

      public CoordinateSpace getCoordinateSpace()
      Gets the coordinate space to which the object's position is relative. The default is world coordinates, but the parameter may specify that the object is relative to the camera in which case it moves when the camera moves.

    • setCoordinateSpace

      public void setCoordinateSpace​(CoordinateSpace coordinateSpace)
      Sets the coordinate space to which the object's position is relative. The default is world coordinates, but the parameter may specify that the object is relative to the camera in which case it moves when the camera moves.

    • worldToObjectCoords

      public Vector2 worldToObjectCoords​(Vector2 worldCoords)
      Translates world coordinates to object coordinates (relative to the top-left corner and indifferent to dimensions).
      Parameters:
      worldCoords - a point in world coordinates
      Returns:
      a point in object coordinates

    • objectToWorldCoords

      public Vector2 objectToWorldCoords​(Vector2 objectCoords)
      Translates objects coordinates to world coordinates
      Parameters:
      objectCoords - a point relative to the top-left corner and indifferent to dimensions
      Returns:
      a point in world coordinates

    • containsPoint

      public boolean containsPoint​(Vector2 point)
      Checks whether the GameObject's collider contains a specified point.
      Parameters:
      point - a point in world coordinates
      Returns:
      true iff the collider contains the given point

    • onMouseAction

      public void onMouseAction​(MouseActionParams params)
      Invoked on the game object in case the mouse has been clicked, pressed, released, or scrolled while the cursor is on top of the game object.
      Parameters:
      params - info regarding the mouse's parameters in this frame and the action that occurred.

    • physics

      public GameObjectPhysics physics()
      access physics-related attributes of the GameObject
